verbs.description: entrail (third-person singular simple present entrails, present participle entrailing, simple past and past participle entrailed)

examples: Trust not any with thy life, credit, or estate: for it is mere folly for a man to entrail himself to his friend; as though, occasion being offered, he shall not dare to become his enemy.

description: From Middle English entraille, from Old French entraille (compare modern French entrailles), from Late Latin intrālia, modification of Latin intrānea, contraction of interāneum (“gut, intestine”), substantive of interāneus (“internal, inward”).

entries.meaning: (usually used in the plural) singular of entrails; an internal organ of an animal.
